Impact of Cu complex anions on CuZnAl intercalated hydrotalcite-like catalysts for low-carbon alcohols synthesis from syngas Shuyuan Wang Writing – original draft Software Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Zhe Hong Validation Lingling Yin Validation Zhihua Gao Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources ⁎ Wei Huang Supervision Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, College of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, Shanxi 030024, China State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, College of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan Shanxi 030024 China State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, College of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024 Shanxi, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Elucidating the structure-performance relationship of catalysts for low-carbon alcohols synthesis from syngas is crucial for designing efficient catalysts. In this study, CuO particle size, reducibility, and the number of oxygen vacancies could be adjusted by changing intercalated Cu complex anions, thereby affecting the catalyst's performance. The characterization results indicated that the insertion of [Cu(C2O4)2]2- between ZnAl layered double hydroxide resulted in the largest CuO particles (26.5 nm), leading to an increase in the metallic copper surface area. Consequently, the highest CO conversion (13.0 %) was achieved without altering alcohol distribution. On the other hand, when [Cu(EDTA)]2- was inserted, the catalyst possessed the smallest CuO particle size (8.9 nm), more abundant oxygen vacancies, and enhanced interaction between Cu species and ZnO, which promoted carbon chain growth and resulted in a high C2+OH proportion of 75.8 %. Our study thus provides a new perspective on catalyst structures for the syngas production of low-carbon alcohols. Graphical Abstract Keywords Cu complex anions CuO particle size Oxygen vacancy Syngas Low-carbon alcohols Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Coal's underutilization and direct combustion have caused substantial environmental damage globally. To solve this problem, coal resources should be used cleanly and efficiently, that was, coal-derived syngas presented the potential to yield low-carbon alcohols [1]. Low-carbon alcohols refer to mixed alcohols composed of normal and isomeric alcohols with carbon numbers from 1–5 in the molecule. Utilized as a clean and renewable energy source, it was applied to the chemical and fuel industries, contributing significantly to the promotion of sustainable development and effective energy use [2–4]. Catalysts were essential to the yield and selectivity of the low-carbon alcohols produced from coal-based syngas. Cu-based catalysts have gained a lot of interest because of their affordable cost and ability to accommodate reaction conditions [5]. At present, researchers have increased the yield of low-carbon alcohols and improved the CO conversion, low-carbon alcohols selectivity, and poisoning resistance of Cu-based catalysts by adjusting the composition, morphology, and crystal structure or introducing additives [6–11]. However, there were still some challenges for Cu-based catalysts. For example, the easy sintering of Cu species caused the deactivation of the catalyst [12,13], and the understanding of the effect of Cu species particle sizes on the low-carbon alcohols selectivity was ambiguous. Therefore, optimizing the design of the catalyst structure and preparation method to improve CO conversion and the proportion of low-carbon alcohols was of great significance for achieving sustainable development of clean energy. The formula for layered double hydroxides (LDHs), resembling hydrotalcite, was represented as [MII 1−x MIII x (OH)2] x+(An−) x/n ·mH2O, where MII and MIII denote divalent and trivalent metal cations, respectively. An− represented an anion, either inorganic or organic, and satisfied the condition 2≤(1 − x)/x≤4. On the layers of LDHs, the metal cations (MII and MIII) could be arbitrarily combined and were highly dispersed. LDHs possessed notable characteristics such as good thermal stability, tunability of interlayer anions (An−), and controllability of crystallite size. Thus, compounds with hydrotalcite-like structures were widely used in the field of catalysis [14–17]. By taking advantage of the anions that could be inserted between the layers of LDHs, a variety of LDHs containing catalytically active ions were prepared. The catalysts of intercalated LDHs exhibited superior selectivity, stability, catalytic activity, and active center dispersion when compared to catalysts made using conventional techniques. Monica et al. employed a co-precipitation method to embed the anionic complex formed between Cu species and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) and citrate into the ZnAl layered double hydroxide layer. The corresponding mixed metal oxide obtained by calcination showed smaller CuO particle sizes than those of catalysts prepared by traditional co-precipitation methods due to an interaction between the complex anion and the layer, which in turn showed higher catalytic activity for catalyzing methane oxidation reactions [18]. Song et al. prepared a POM cluster intercalated MgAl-LDH catalyst of [WZn3(H2O)2(ZnW9O34)2]12−, where Mg/Al=3. The material exhibited significantly enhanced selectivity towards aldoximes and ketoximes under solvent-free conditions. The reason was that LDHs could offer a "flexible" confined space that allowed for adjustments by modifying the size and arrangement of guest molecules. The flexible interlayer space could accommodate not only small-sized components but also larger catalytic sites with substantial volumes [19]. The Pd/MgAl-LDH intercalated structure catalyst prepared using an ion exchange method had a Pd particle size of 2.66 nm and showed more Pd-LDH interface positions with better catalytic activity. When the catalyst was prepared using the impregnation method, PdCl4 2- was mainly adsorbed and deposited on the surface of LDH and did not enter the interlayer. The Pd particle size was 3.56 nm. It was indicated that the intercalation structure could adjust the particle size of the active metal between layers [20]. Based on the advantage of intercalated LDHs, Cu-based catalysts that employed various Cu complex anions to intercalate ZnAl layered double hydroxide (HT-ZnAl) as precursors were designed in this paper, and a mixed metal oxide catalyst with different CuO particle sizes after calcination was obtained. The aim was to investigate the effect of different Cu complex anions on the structure and performance of CuZnAl intercalated hydrotalcite-like catalysts for low-carbon alcohols synthesis from syngas. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O, Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, and NaOH were obtained from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., ltd., China. C10H16N2O8, C6H5Na3O7, Na2C2O4, and C6H15NO3 were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., China. NaNO3 was purchased from Chengdu Kelong Chemical Co., Ltd., China. The chemical reagents were analytical grade and used without further purification. CO, H2, N2, Ar, and He, with purities of 99.99 %, were provided by the Product of Taiyuan Fujiang Special Gas Co., ltd., China. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Four complexing agents with different ionic radii and strong complexing ability with Cu, namely [Cu(EDTA)]2-, [Cu(CA)]-, [Cu(C2O4)2]2-, and [Cu(TEA)]2-, were chosen to form Cu complex anions. These Cu complex anions were subsequently intercalated into the HT-ZnAl using the co-precipitation method. The molar ratio of Cu⁚Zn⁚Al was 0.5⁚2⁚1 for all samples. The precipitate was calcined to obtain four catalysts, named HT-Cu(EDTA), HT-Cu(CA), HT-Cu(C2O4)2, and HT-Cu(TEA), respectively. Unintercalated samples were also prepared for comparison, denoted as HT-CuZnAl and HT-ZnAl. The catalysts were tableted and granulated, and the 40–60 mesh size catalysts were taken for activity evaluation. The process of catalyst preparation was as follows. Cu complex anions: Dissolve a certain amount of C10H16N2O8, C6H5Na3O7, Na2C2O4, and C6H15NO3 in 100 mL deionized water, respectively. An appropriate amount of Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O was added to the above solutions while maintaining the pH at 9.0 by adding NaOH (2 mol/L) further. HT-Cu(EDTA): Firstly, Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O and Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (ZnAl = 2, molar ratio) were mixed and dissolved in 200 mL of deionized water. The NaOH (250 mL, 2 mol/L) solution was used as the precipitant and controlled the pH at 9.0, and then the two solutions were added dropwise into the three-necked flask containing [Cu(EDTA)]2- at room temperature. The process used boiled and cooled deionized water and maintained an N2 atmosphere to prevent interference from CO2 in the air. Subsequently, the solution was stirred in a 308 K water bath for 48 h to form a precipitate, followed by centrifugation and repeated washing with deionized water until the pH became neutral. Finally, the obtained precipitate was dried at 353 K for 12 h and calcined at 623 K for 4 h to obtain HT-Cu(EDTA). The preparation process of HT-Cu(CA), HT-Cu(C2O4)2, and HT-Cu(TEA) was the same as above, only changing the corresponding Cu complex anions. HT-CuZnAl: Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O, and Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (Cu⁚Zn⁚Al = 0.5⁚2⁚1, molar ratio) were mixed and dissolved in 200 mL deionized water as a salt solution. An alkali solution with c(CO3 2-) = 2c(Al3+) and c(NaOH) = 1.5 mol/L was prepared as the precipitant. Then, the above salt and alkali solutions were added dropwise into the three-necked flask at room temperature. Subsequently, the solution was stirred constantly for 30 min, and the pH was controlled at 9.0 to form a precipitate. The so-prepared precipitate was aged in a 348 K oven for 12 h, followed by centrifugation and repeated washing with deionized water until the pH became neutral. Finally, the obtained precipitate was dried at 353 K for 12 h and calcined at 623 K for 4 h to obtain HT-CuZnAl. HT-ZnAl: Firstly, Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O and Al(NO3)3·9 H2O were dissolved in deionized water with a molar ratio of 2⁚1 to prepare a 150 mL solution. NaOH solution (2 mol/L) was used as the precipitant, and then the salt solution and alkali solution were added dropwise to the three-necked flask containing the NaNO3 (1 mol/L) solution while maintaining the pH of 8.0 to form a precipitate at room temperature. Deionized water cooled after boiling was used throughout the process, and the N2 atmosphere was maintained. After the dropwise addition was completed, continue stirring in the water bath for 2 h, followed by centrifugation and repeated washing with deionized water until the pH became neutral, and dried in the air overnight at 353 K to obtain HT-ZnAl. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns were acquired on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer with a Cu-Kα radiation source (40 kV, 40 mA). The scanning rate was 8°/min, and the scanning range was 5° to 85°. FT-IR characterization was performed on a Bruker INVENIO S infrared spectrometer. A small amount of the sample was mixed with 100 mg of KBr powder, ground, and pressed into tablets for testing. The scanning range was 400–4000 cm-1. The texture parameters of the catalyst were measured by a Quantachrome QDS-30 physical adsorption instrument. First, the sample was vacuum degassed at 473 K for 4 h, and then the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm was recorded at liquid nitrogen temperature (76 K). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the specific surface area, and the BJH method was used to calculate the average pore diameter and pore volume. The morphology of the catalyst was analyzed using a Zeiss Gemini 300 scanning electron microscope (SEM) with an acceleration voltage of 15 kV and a secondary electron resolution of 0.8 nm, and the elemental composition of the catalyst was determined with an energy spectrometer (EDS). TEM images were collected on a Talos 200x instrument with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The sample was dispersed in an ethanol solution and subjected to ultrasonic treatment, and then a drop of the solution was deposited on a carbon-coated copper microgrid for measurement. N2O titration experiments were conducted on a TP-5080D titrator (Tianjin Xianquan Company). The sample was first pretreated at 423 K at an N2 (30 mL·min−1) flow rate for 30 min, followed by cooling to 323 K. Then the H2/N2 mixture was injected to reduce CuO to Cu. Subsequently, the temperature was increased from 323 K to 783 K at a heating rate of 10 K·min−1. The reduced catalyst was cooled to 323 K, and N2 flow was introduced for 30 min to remove residual H2. Subsequently, N2O (30 mL·min−1) was then introduced to oxidize the surface metallic copper to Cu2O, and N2 was used to purge for 30 min to remove residual N2O. Finally, the surface Cu2O was reduced again using the same reduction process, and the H2 consumption was recorded as A (mmol·g−1). The copper dispersion (D Cu) and the Cu surface area (S Cu) were calculated as follows: (1) D Cu = 2 A × M Cu / W Cu × 100 % (2) S Cu = 2 A × N A / ( W Cu × 1.4 × 10 19 ) Where M Cu = 63.46 g·mol−1, W Cu was the actual Cu loading by ICP-OES, N A referred to Avogadro’s constant, and 1.4 × 1019 was the copper atom surface density per square meter. Elemental composition was tested on the ICP-OES (Agilent 5110). A certain amount of the sample was taken for digestion. After digestion, the volume was adjusted to 25 mL as the test solution. H2-TPR was carried out on a TP-5080 chemical adsorption instrument, and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to measure the reduction temperature and monitor hydrogen consumption. Before H2-TPR analysis, samples (50 mg) were pretreated in a He atmosphere at 423 K for 30 min to remove adsorbed water and impurities. After the temperature dropped to 323 K, reducing gas (5 % H2/N2) was introduced at a flow rate of 30 mL⋅min-1, and the temperature was raised to 780 K at a heating rate of 10 K⋅min-1 to perform programmed temperature reduction. XPS was measured on the AXIS SUPRA03030708, equipped with an Al Kα radiation source. The vacuum degree of the analysis chamber was 9.5×10-9 Pa, and the operating voltage was 14.95 kV. All binding energies were corrected with reference to the standard C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. 2.4 Catalyst evaluation The CO hydrogenation performance of the catalyst was evaluated using an automatic four-channel parallel reaction device. Place 3 mL of catalyst (40–60 mesh) into four stainless steel tubes. First, the catalysts were pre-reduced at 523 K for 2 h in a mixed gas (N2⁚H2 = 4⁚1) with a flow rate of 100 mL⋅min-1, and then the catalysts were evaluated under the conditions of a temperature of 553 K, a pressure of 4.0 MPa, a syngas (H2⁚CO = 1⁚1) feed flow of 100 mL⋅min-1, and a gas space velocity (GHSV) of 2000 h-1. The reaction products were analyzed using a Huaai GC-9560 gas chromatograph. The gas chromatograph included a flame ionization detector (FID) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The FID was used to detect CH3OH, dimethyl ether (DME), C2+OH, and hydrocarbons (CH) in the reaction outlet gas. The TCD was used to detect H2, CO, and CO2 online. The liquid phase products collected after gas-liquid condensation separation were connected to the FID for offline analysis. Quantitative analysis of each component was performed using the external standard method. After the carbon balance, the conversion rate of CO (X CO) and the selectivity of each component (S i) were calculated as follows: (3) X CO = ∑ n i g + ∑ n i l n CO i × 100 % (4) S i = n i g + n i l ∑ n i g + ∑ n i l × 100 % Where X CO represented the CO conversion, S i represented the selectivity of product i, i was all C-containing compounds except CO in the gas and liquid phase products, n (CO)in was the number of moles of CO in the raw gas, n i (g) and n i (l) were the number of moles of carbon atoms in the inlet and outlet gas and liquid phase component i, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD characterization Fig. 1 showed the XRD patterns of different Cu complex anion intercalated HT-ZnAl. Before the calcination (Fig. 1a), all samples displayed hydrotalcite-like 6.16°(003), 12.26°(006), and 60.34°(110) characteristic diffraction peaks [21], and no other diffraction peaks appeared in the XRD patterns, showing that hydrotalcite-like structures were successfully prepared. Moreover, the unintercalated HT-CuZnAl had a good crystalline form, and its (003) crystal plane appeared at 2θ =11.66°. Compared with HT-ZnAl and HT-CuZnAl, the (003) crystal plane of HT-Cu(EDTA), HT-Cu(CA), HT-Cu(C2O4)2, and HT-Cu(TEA) shifted to a lower 2θ angle. To show the change clearly, details of the range 2θ = 5–15° were displayed in Fig. 1b. Table 1 showed the unit cell parameters of different samples. The interplanar spacing (d 003 and d 110) of the (003) and (110) crystal planes of hydrotalcite-like were calculated according to Bragg's Law (nλ = 2dsinθ) formula. The unit cell parameter a was related to the distance of metal ions in the talc laminate. The unit cell parameter c was the spacing between hydrotalcite-like laminates. As seen from Table 1, the intercalation structure of the precursor d 003 was between 0.8978 and 1.4331 nm, which was greater than the non-intercalated sample (0.7580 nm). The literature reported that the average thickness of the HT-ZnAl layer was 0.48 nm [22]. It was proved that Cu complex anions with different ionic radii entered the HT-ZnAl layer, causing the interlayer spacing to increase to varying degrees, that was, the unit cell parameter c also increased. Changing the intercalation anion, d 110 and unit cell parameter a hardly changed. The above description showed that CuZnAl precursors with good intercalation structures were prepared, and there was a strong interaction between the intercalation anions and the HT-ZnAl layer [23]. After the calcination (Fig. 1c), the hydrotalcite-like characteristic diffraction peaks of all catalysts disappeared, and the diffraction peaks of ZnO and CuO appeared, suggesting that the hydrotalcite-like structure was completely destroyed and transformed into metal oxides [18]. The diffraction peaks of Al oxides were not detected for all catalysts, indicating that they were in an amorphous state. Notably, the diffraction peaks of CuO were not observed for the HT-Cu(TEA) catalyst due to CuO being in an amorphous state. After the reaction (Fig. 1d), all catalysts highlighted diffraction peaks of Cu0 and ZnO, suggesting that the Cu species were reduced. It could be found that the diffraction peak of HT-Cu(EDTA) was a harp, implying a higher crystallinity. The silica diffraction peaks occurred owing to the catalyst and the fine quartz sand mixing together and not being separated. 3.2 FT-IR Fig. 2 showed the infrared spectra of catalysts after the calcination. The broad peak at 3460 cm-1 and the absorption peak at 1646 cm-1 were ascribed to the stretching vibration and bending vibration of the hydroxyl groups between the hydrotalcite layers [24], respectively. The absorption peak at 1384 cm-1 was caused by the N−O stretching vibration of NO3 - in the catalysts, suggesting that a part of NO3 - between layers was preserved after the calcination [25]. No characteristic peak of the complexing agent was observed. The absorption peak at 535 cm-1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of the metal oxide M−O, meaning that the hydrotalcite-like structure transformed into a mixed metal oxide after the calcination [24]. XRD also proved this. 3.3 N2 adsorption-desorption characterization Fig. 3 showed the N2 adsorption-desorption curves and pore size distribution of the Cu complex anion intercalated HT-ZnAl catalyst after the calcination. All catalysts exhibited IV isotherms, demonstrating that the catalysts had a mesoporous structure. However, the shapes of the hysteresis loops were somewhat different, implying various porous structures. The isotherm of the HT-CuZnAl catalyst showed an H3 type hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of slit pores. Nevertheless, the hysteresis loops of the four intercalated catalysts were of the H4 type, which was attributed to the narrow fissure hole. As shown in Table 2, the specific surface area of the catalysts decreased in the following order: HT-Cu(EDTA)>HT-CuZnAl>HT-Cu(CA)>HT-Cu(TEA)>HT-Cu(C2O4)2. Moreover, the average pore diameter of the non-intercalated catalyst HT-CuZnAl was maximized at 20 nm, larger than that of intercalated structure catalysts, attributed to the Cu complex anions blocking the pores during the calcination process. The HT-Cu(C2O4)2 catalyst had the largest pore volume (0.21 cm3/g). The results indicated a significant influence of Cu complex anions on the textural properties. 3.4 SEM characterization The surface morphology of the four intercalated structure catalysts before and after the calcination was analyzed by SEM. All catalysts exhibited lamellar structures both before and after the calcination, as Fig. 4 illustrates. Before the calcination, the layered structure of HT-Cu(EDTA) was more pronounced and regular, and the lamellar particle size was larger than 300 nm (Fig. 4a), while the lamellar stacking of other intercalated samples showed an irregular shape and the laminate's particle sizes were all less than 300 nm (Fig. 4b–d). After the calcination, the intercalated catalyst layer's particle sizes were less than 300 nm (Fig. 4e–h). The arrangement of the layers was more disorderly due to the complex anions between the hydrotalcite layers being decomposed during the calcination process, resulting in the removal of hydroxyl sites on the laminates and the destruction of the layered structure. However, hydrotalcite had a unique topological effect in which the highly mixed metal oxides still exhibited a lamellar morphology [26]. All intercalated catalysts had uniformly distributed Cu, Zn, and Al elements on the surface both before and after the calcination, according to the corresponding EDS mapping. 3.5 TEM characterization The catalysts were subjected to TEM characterization in order to measure the CuO particle sizes. As shown in Fig. 5a–5e, all catalysts exhibited irregular lamellar structures and non-uniform CuO particle sizes. The average particle size of CuO in the catalyst could be calculated from the CuO particle size distribution diagram (the results were shown in Table 3). This calculated result served as the basis for discussing the following CuO particle size. From the data in Table 3, it could be seen that the CuO particles of HT-Cu(EDTA) were the smallest among the samples analyzed, suggesting a stronger confinement effect of the laminate, which obviously limited the agglomeration and growth of CuO. Conversely, the CuO particles of HT-Cu(C2O4)2 were the largest, indicating CuO experienced a reduction in the confinement effect of the laminate and tended towards agglomeration. The lattice spacing was found to be 2.52 Å and 2.48 Å, respectively, from the HRTEM image of the HT-Cu(EDTA) catalyst (Fig. 5f), which corresponded to the CuO(11−1) and ZnO(101) facet. This was consistent with the XRD pattern, and the interface between CuO and ZnO could be clearly observed, denoting that the Cu species had a strong interaction with ZnO on the layer, which was beneficial to the catalytic activity. As for HT-CuZnAl and HT-Cu(CA) catalysts, the HRTEM images (Fig. 5g–h) observed lattice spacings corresponding to CuO(11−1) and ZnO(101) facets, but there was no obvious interface between the two facets, suggesting that CuO and ZnO did not interact strongly. 3.6 N2O titration In order to study the metallic copper surface area (S Cu) and dispersion (D Cu), the N2O titration test was performed on the catalysts after calcination, and the results were shown in Table 3. Except for the HT-Cu(TEA) catalyst, D Cu of other catalysts from large to small were HT-Cu(C2O4)2, HT-CuZnAl, HT-Cu(EDTA), and HT-Cu(CA). The HT-Cu(TEA) catalyst had the largest D Cu and S Cu due to the fact that [Cu(TEA)]2- was difficult to intercalate into the HT-ZnAl layer, and Cu species leaching occurred during the preparation step [27]. The Cu element content in HT-Cu(TEA) measured by ICP-OES was only 3.1 %, which also confirmed this (Table 3). Combined with the CuO particle size calculated by TEM, it could be seen that, except for HT-Cu(TEA), S Cu of the other four catalysts showed a slowly increasing trend as the CuO particles increased (Table 3), and the change of D Cu was not evident (Table 3). Among them, the HT-Cu(C2O4)2 catalyst had the largest CuO particles and S Cu, which would strengthen the contact between CO and the active site Cu in the catalyst, thereby increasing the CO conversion [27]. 3.7 H2-TPR characterization The H2-TPR profiles of HT-ZnAl catalysts intercalated with different Cu complex anions were displayed in Fig. 6. It could be seen from Fig. 6 that all catalysts had some reduction peaks in the low-temperature α region (220–280 °C) and high-temperature β region (280–350 °C), meaning that their particle sizes were not uniform, which was confirmed by TEM. The reduction peaks of the catalyst were all attributed to the reduction of CuO to Cu0 since, according to the literature, ZnO and Al2O3 would not be reduced by hydrogen below 350 °C [28]. The low-temperature reduction peak α was attributed to the reduction of smaller CuO particles, and the high-temperature reduction peak β corresponded to the reduction of larger CuO particles [29]. As illustrated in Fig. 6, in contrast to the non-intercalated HT-CuZnAl catalyst, the high-temperature reduction peak β of the intercalated catalyst was shifted toward high temperature, signaling that the reduction of big CuO particles was more difficult. In addition, the temperature of peak α of HT-Cu(EDTA) was lower than that of other catalysts due to the synergistic effect between CuO and ZnO, which produced strong interactions in well-dispersed particles and shifted the reduction temperature toward a lower temperature [30]. TEM characterization also confirmed the existence of this strong interaction (Fig. 5f). Therefore, the CuO particles of HT-Cu(EDTA) were more easily reducible than other catalysts. The hydrogen consumption of the catalysts was shown in Table 3. In accordance with Table 3, the hydrogen consumption in the low-temperature area followed the following order: HT-Cu(TEA)<HT-Cu(C2O4)2<HT-CuZnAl<HT-Cu(CA)<HT-Cu(EDTA). The order of hydrogen consumption in the high-temperature area from small to large was HT-Cu(TEA), HT-Cu(EDTA), HT-Cu(CA), HT-CuZnAl, and HT-Cu(C2O4)2. Moreover, with the exception of HT-Cu(TEA), the α/β value of the other catalysts exhibited an inverse relationship with the CuO particle size determined by TEM. In other words, the contribution of the α peak area to the H2-TPR pattern decreased as the CuO particle size increased, meaning that the insertion of different anions could alter the particle size distribution of CuO. Among these catalysts, HT-Cu(EDTA) demonstrated the largest α/β value, signifying that the proportion of smaller CuO particles that could be reduced was the largest. This observation was corroborated by TEM analysis, confirming that the CuO particles in the HT-Cu(EDTA) catalyst were the smallest. Conversely, the α/β value of HT-Cu(C2O4)2 was the smallest, indicating that the proportion of reducible, larger CuO particles was highest, which was similarly verified by the TEM result. 3.8 XPS characterization The surface properties of catalysts were studied using XPS. The Cu 2p spectra of the catalysts after the calcination were shown in Fig. 7a. All catalysts, except for HT-Cu(TEA), had two main peaks, and the corresponding binding energies were ∼933.9 eV and ∼953.4 eV, belonging to Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2, respectively. The satellite peaks oscillated strongly between ∼940.0 eV and ∼945.0 eV, proving the existence of Cu2+, which was consistent with the XRD patterns. It should be noted that the satellite peak also appeared for HT-Cu(TEA), but its binding energy was 932.9 eV, lower than other catalysts, because TEA reduced some Cu2+ during the preparation process [31,32], leading to the coexistence of Cu2+ and Cu+/Cu0 on the catalyst surface. It was further confirmed through the lowest hydrogen consumption in H2-TPR characterization. Furthermore, in comparison with the non-intercalated HT-CuZnAl catalyst, the Cu 2p 3/2 binding energy of the intercalated catalyst slightly shifted to lower values, signifying that intercalation influenced the electron distribution of Cu due to the coordination bonds between central ions and ligands formed during the intercalation process. The O 1 s spectra of the catalysts after calcination were displayed in Fig. 7b. Lattice oxygen (OL) and adsorbed oxygen (OA), which were the two forms of oxygen that were detected, were centered at around 530.1 eV and 531.6 eV, respectively. OA/OL represented the relative content of oxygen vacancies. Through calculation, the relative content of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst followed the order: HT-Cu(C2O4)2<HT-CuZnAl<HT-Cu(TEA)<HT-Cu(CA)<HT-Cu(EDTA). With the exception of HT-Cu(C2O4)2, intercalated catalysts exhibited more oxygen vacancies, with HT-Cu(EDTA) showing the highest oxygen vacancy content. 3.9 Evaluation of catalytic activity The performance of different Cu complex anions intercalated HT-ZnAl catalysts for CO hydrogenation reactions was evaluated under the conditions of 553 K, 4.0 MPa, H2/CO=1⁚1, and GHSV=2000 h-1. The reaction was carried out for 120 h. As shown in Fig. 8a, the difference in Cu complex anions had a significant impact on the catalytic activity. The non-intercalated HT-CuZnAl catalyst achieved a CO conversion of 10.5 %, coupled with a total alcohol selectivity of 75.3 %. The CO conversion and product selectivity of the HT-Cu(CA) catalyst closely resembled those of the HT-CuZnAl catalyst. Moreover, it can be found that the CO conversion of the HT-Cu(EDTA) catalyst was 9.5 %, the selectivity for total alcohol (5.6 %) was the lowest, and the selectivity for by-product hydrocarbons (16.7 %) and CO2 (77.5 %) was the highest. The high CO2 selectivity might be due to the catalyst's severe water gas shift reaction. As for the HT-Cu(C2O4)2 catalyst, the CO conversion was the highest, reaching 13.0 %. Meanwhile, the total alcohol (ROH) selectivity was 74.0 %. Unlike the other catalysts, the HT-Cu(TEA) catalyst recorded the lowest CO conversion at 5.9 % but exhibited the highest dimethyl ether selectivity at 4.5 %. Fig. 8b showed the alcohol distribution and C2+OH fraction of different catalysts. The proportion of C2+OH in the HT-Cu(EDTA) catalyst was as high as 75.8 %. Except for HT-Cu(EDTA), the alcohol product of other catalysts was predominantly methanol, meaning a relatively poor carbon chain growth ability for these intercalated anion catalysts. Particularly, the C2+OH proportion of the non-intercalated HT-CuZnAl catalyst was only 8.6 %. The characterization analysis indicated the HT-Cu(EDTA) catalyst had the smallest CuO particles and strong interaction between CuO and ZnO, thus resulting in CuO being more easily reduced, which was conducive to exposing more active sites and promoting the adsorption and activation of more reactant molecules. According to reports, abundant oxygen vacancies enhanced the interaction between Cu and ZnO, resulting in the generation of more defect structures, including Cu0 and Znδ+. Oxygen vacancies facilitated the activation of CO, participating in the formation of HCOO* and CHxO* intermediates, ultimately leading to C−C coupling of CHx* with CHxO*/CO* at Znδ+ sites, generating C2+OH [33]. In this study, XPS results indicated that the oxygen vacancy content was altered by changing the types of intercalated ions. Among them, the HT-Cu(EDTA) catalyst exhibited the highest oxygen vacancy content, resulting in the highest proportion of C2+OH, which was in accordance with the literature. However, there was no consistent relationship observed between the number of oxygen vacancies and C2+OH selectivity for other catalysts. It was found that the number of oxygen vacancies varied, but their alcohol distribution remained relatively stable, which implied that oxygen vacancies were not the only factor in the generation of C2+OH. Fig. 9 illustrated the dependency of catalyst structure and CO conversion on CuO particle size. Due to the Cu element content of the HT-Cu(TEA) catalyst being only 3.1 %, it was not discussed in this section. The size of CuO particles, tuned by different intercalated anion types, had a significant impact on the catalyst's specific surface area, Cu surface area, hydrogen consumption, and CO conversion. As the CuO particle size increased from 8.9 nm to 26.5 nm, the catalyst's specific surface area and the hydrogen consumption in the low-temperature area decreased, showing an inverse relationship with the CuO particle size (Fig. 9a and d). In contrast, Cu surface area, hydrogen consumption in the high-temperature area, and CO conversion showed an increasing trend (Fig. 9c, e, and f). Fig. 9b showed that Cu dispersion did not show an apparent dependence on the particle size. Overall, the Cu surface area expanded with increasing CuO particle size in CuZnAl intercalated hydrotalcite-like catalysts, exposing more active sites and increasing CO conversion. Therefore, the largest CuO particles and highest CO conversion were found in the HT-Cu(C2O4)2 catalyst. The HT-Cu(EDTA) catalyst exhibited the smallest CuO particles that were more readily reducible by hydrogen. This catalyst possessed abundant oxygen vacancies and strengthened the interaction between Cu species and ZnO, hence enhancing the carbon chain growth, leading to an increased proportion of C2+OH and changing the alcohol distribution. Compared with the non-intercalated catalyst HT-CuZnAl, other intercalated catalysts displayed nearly the same alcohol distribution, with methanol constituting the majority. 4 Conclusion Different Cu complex anions intercalations significantly impacted the structure and performance of hydrotalcite-like catalysts for low-carbon alcohols synthesis from syngas. Characterization results revealed that LDHs with different types of Cu complex anions as precursors were able to modulate the CuO particle sizes within a specific range. The specific surface area of the catalyst and the hydrogen consumption in the low-temperature region decreased with the CuO particle size. Moreover, increased CuO particle size led to a corresponding increase in the Cu surface area, hydrogen consumption in the high-temperature region, and CO conversion. Using [Cu(C2O4)2]2- as the intercalated anion resulted in the largest CuO particles, leading to an increased Cu surface area and more active sites and ultimately achieving a maximum CO conversion of 13.0 %. On the other hand, when [Cu(EDTA)]2- was chosen as the intercalated anion, CuO particles were the smallest, facilitating their exposure on the surface of layers and making them more easily reducible. This favored the catalyst with abundant oxygen vacancies, enhancing the interaction between Cu species and ZnO and promoting contact between Cu species and CO, which improved the carbon chain growth. Consequently, the C2+OH/ROH ratio of the HT-Cu(EDTA) catalyst reached 75.8 %, indicating its superior performance compared to other catalysts. This study provided a new perspective for designing catalyst structures for the synthesis of low-carbon alcohols from syngas. CRediT authorship contribution statement Lingling Yin: Validation. coredata.dc:description: Elucidating the structure-performance relationship of catalysts for low-carbon alcohols synthesis from syngas is crucial for designing efficient catalysts. In this study, CuO particle size, reducibility, and the number of oxygen vacancies could be adjusted by changing intercalated Cu complex anions, thereby affecting the catalyst's performance. The characterization results indicated that the insertion of [Cu(C2O4)2]2- between ZnAl layered double hydroxide resulted in the largest CuO particles (26.5 nm), leading to an increase in the metallic copper surface area. Consequently, the highest CO conversion (13.0 %) was achieved without altering alcohol distribution. On the other hand, when [Cu(EDTA)]2- was inserted, the catalyst possessed the smallest CuO particle size (8.9 nm), more abundant oxygen vacancies, and enhanced interaction between Cu species and ZnO, which promoted carbon chain growth and resulted in a high C2+OH proportion of 75.8 %. Our study thus provides a new perspective on catalyst structures for the syngas production of low-carbon alcohols.
